text: I'm Anthony Romero the national director
of the American civil liberties
Union well remarkably little has changed
thus far uh since uh President Obama
took office when it comes to a
Guantanamo we were we were delighted we
were elated when his first three
executive orders in the first 24 hours
of his presidency said that he would
shut down Guantanamo within a year that
he would ban torture un equivocally and
it was shut down to secret prisons that
were being run by the CIA we thought we
were off to a pretty good start that
seemed like a civil liberties Trifecta
to us but frankly in the last six seven
months that we've seen since those first
executive orders there's been very
little substantive difference in the way
in which the policies are executed in
even the maneuvering of the Obama
Administration they have very much
backrack on those initial promises on
shutting down the military commissions
uh unequivocally we Fe now that we're in
a very different uh political
environment where people want to believe
and have faith in this President he came
in with enormous popularity with an
enormous mandate to get us back on track
he still commands enormous popularity in
in the public opinion polls And yet when
you look at the substantive policies of
this President and you compare them to
those of George Bush they're not all
that different the rhetoric is certainly
much different the values that he speaks
of are are are newly refined
but the substantive policy outcomes are
not that different and that perhaps is
what concerns us the most that when
people have finally let down their guard
and believe that we're back on track to
restore civil liberties that in fact we
have an Administration that's now
mumbling when it comes to those initial
promises they
made well the president uh has uh banned
torture uh in under his administration
and he has rejected the enhanced
interrogation techniques that are now
Infamous in the office of legal council
memos that we secured the ACLU secured
through the uh litigation under the
Freedom of Information Act so we we're
back now to where we were pre 911 we
don't torture we don't abuse we follow
the Geneva conventions the fact is that
there's still a a lot of gray area that
the president has said that we won't use
these very aggressive torture techniques
but we're not entirely sure about these
coerced or these enhanced interrogation
techniques how far far beyond where has
he drawn the line we really don't fully
know uh it's clear to us in some of the
initial discussions we've had with the
administration some of these rules that
regarding the guantan military
commissions that while they've banned
the use of evidence gleaned from torture
it's certainly possible in fact we
expect them to use interrogation uh
techniques or use evidence gleaned from
Co from coerced interrogation techniques
that could be fall a little bit below
the torture line but still would be uh
ille legal in in the pre- 911 context we
don't fully know what's going on frankly
in some of the other sites we we're
saying we want to close
Guantanamo but we're reading even in in
these recent newspapers about the won
mess at BAM uh where there just in
today's newspaper we read about
detainees not having access to lawyers
awful conditions refusing to come out of
their celles as a way to protest their
inhumane treatment and whenever you have
a prison or or a detention center that
is not accessible to members of the
press or public or Advocates like us at
the ACLU that's a recipe for abuse what
can happen behind closed doors that
can't be penetrated can in fact lead to
the type of uh abusive techniques that
we saw uh under the the Bush
Administration what I think the
president fails to understand and
perhaps by the fact that he always
refers to himself as commanderin-chief
of the nation is a fact that a concern
for civil liberties and human rights on
the one hand doesn't obviate or
necessarily be uh won't necessarily be
at odds with a concern of making sure
you have National Security and enforce
the nation's uh security as
commanderin-chief and we have the
president now who I I think is
wrongheaded in his unwillingness to look
back uh the President says that he
wishes to look forward that this is not
a time for recriminations this is not a
time for finger pointing this is not a
Time for partisan squabbling but frankly
unless you look back and unless you
prosecute the individuals who authorized
the torture and abuse who authorized at
the highest levels of our government you
create a moral hazard in our government
it means that you can break the law and
get away with it and so individuals down
the chain of command in the Department
of Defense in the CIA who broke the law
under President Bush who are not being
prosecuted for what they did and what
they knew would happen there's impunity
in in the rank of the government and
unless you were really willing to
prosecute individuals of the highest
levels of our government who authorize
and enabled torture and abuse to happen
on in our name you're going to allow
that impunity to exist and you're never
going to be able to get us back to a
place where where uh torture and abuse
of detainees is just anathema uh you'll
always have the question in your in in
people's minds and soldiers or the CIA
officers Minds maybe I can do it maybe I
can get away with it maybe this is the
best way to protect America and unless
you prosecute the individuals who
authorize at the highest levels you're
going to have that doubt and you're
going to have the the remains of that
bush policy creep into the Obama
Administration absolutely if not higher
certainly Cheney certainly Addington
certainly you and Gonzalez we have D
Cheney still say that we never tortured
uh that we don't we didn't torture
people on his watch well that's
obviously not the case we have the
documents to show it from our Freedom of
Information Act litigation there are
thousands of photo photos that Obama
refuses to release that would show in
very explicit detail and troubling
detail what exactly torture looks like
and I the idea that we still are having
a debate about whether or not we did or
didn't torture when the facts are clear
and unequivocal whether or not torture
should be or should not be allowed what
to what level can you have cruel unusual
and degrading treatment that doesn't
rise the level of torture those are
troubling questions that are still roing
within the Obama Administration and
because we haven't had a clear decisive
action to break what the past to
prosecute those who broke the law that
doubt and that ambiguity is going to
continue well we hear those arguments we
hear those arguments directly from the
president himself either in closed door
meetings or in his speeches and and the
concern that that America can't afford
to spend time with some of the most
fundamental uh values of the American
Republic is really giving us too short
shrift I mean certainly no one argues
that the president has been dealt a very
difficult hand with two Wars raging the
healthc care reform debate which seems
to sometimes be going off track the
economy collapsing but frankly America
is a lot more than just the the bank
statements or the assets the financial
assets of our nation America as
America's greatest assets also have to
do with our values and if we would not
be arguing with the fact if dict Cheney
and Addington and others had gone into
Fort Knox and robbed America of a
billion dollars we would not be talking
about whether or not we ought to be
prosecuting them for those crimes and
yet when they authorize torture and
abuse at the highest levels the fact
that we're willing to look the other way
and say well those assets don't really
count as much as the financial assets
that's just not true I mean America was
founded both on a concern for economic
prosperity and taxation without
representation and concerns about the
American colonies fighting the British
crown but they were also fighting
tyranny they were fighting for justice
they were fighting for due process and
those founding documents had much more
to do with certain core aspirations and
values that we cannot afford to put on a
back burner and say we don't have the
time or the energy or or the luxury to
deal with these issues those are as much
about our patrimony as anything that we
own or might own or might sell or might
transact or might import or export what
we have best is our our core commitment
to those values which have been severely
uh undercut over the last eight
years you move them State Side uh our
states and our prisons are perfectly
equipped to handle terrorism suspects uh
we have a number of some very high level
terrorism suspects who've been convicted
convicted who are being held in our in
our nation's prisons you would make sure
you put the best prosecutors uh working
on those cases you throw all the
evidence you can amass from from the FBI
the CIA the Department of Defense the
the Department of State you put them in
front of a legitimate federal court
that's tried and true that's been used
in hundreds of cases to prosecute
terrorism cases over the last 15 20
years and you use our court system uh
that's not what they're going down the P
the path uh the president now is trying
to Tinker with the Guantanamo military
commissions if he ships the prisoners on
Shore he now wants to uh amarate
in their words some of the worst
problems of the military commissions act
the president made rather clear when he
was candidate Obama and not President
Obama that he would reject the military
commissions act well you know tinkering
at the edges of the military commissions
act doesn't sound like rejecting the
military commissions act you need to
just ship them States side prosecute
them throw the book at them and if you
succeed detain them for whatever period
of time is properly determined by a
federal judge and if you don't succeed
in a conviction they have to be released
that's that's our legal
system America has a remarkable history
of of of both protecting civil liberties
and trampling on them I mean surely we
have to understand that America was
really at the Forefront of pushing
through a concern for human rights in
the aftermath of World War II it was the
atrocities that we saw with the Germans
and with with uh the others uh the
Italians and the Japanese that made his
C ify under the UN Universal Declaration
of Human Rights a uniform code for the
protection of human rights that was
America's patrimony as much as anything
else that was Elanor Rosevelt and FDR
who who did all that and frankly it
served as a model for many of the
Nations uh leading many of the world's
leading Nations many of the world's
leading industrial e countries but
frankly what's happened over the last
eight years has been that we set these
rules and Norms up we've espoused them
we've championed them for decades and we
broke them we went back on those
commitments and those promises we
thought that the rules didn't have to
apply to us that the Chinese shouldn't
torture but we can that the Cubans
shouldn't hold people definitely without
charge or trial but we can that we can
hide things from the public and the
press and Congress in America in a way
that we would denounce any uh country
any government from doing that to their
citizens and so what we've seen is just
the fact that there's been an enormous
amount of hypocrisy
of of double standards uh and America
that always championed these issues for
other countries and said it would these
were the core issues for us in our
nation that this in fact now is the
rules are different for us uh and unless
we take that headon uh that that double
standard that that hypocrisy that we get
criticized about overseas will certainly
continue we still see in fact that the
that this this Administration is very
closed when it comes to matters of
National Security uh we think it's a
huge mistake that the president decided
to try to shut down the release of more
than 2,000 photographs that show torture
and abuse in Afghanistan in Iraq at
Guantanamo this is a lawsuit just to be
clear this is a lawsuit we filed in uh
2003 we filed this lawsuit asking the
government for any and all documents
that talked about torture and abuse
happening uh on uh on detainees held by
the American government we didn't know
what was happening we just we were
fishing uh then the photographs of Abu
gra come to light in 2004 and all a
sudden this lawsuit grows into enormous
significance where we begin to pull out
documents from the FBI from the
Department of Defense from the
CIA and then we argue and we litigate
over the number of years about whether
or not the word document includes the
photographs photographs uh taken or held
by the US government
and after winning at two different
courts and and having the government
appeal with both of our wins at those
levels the whole the justice department
said okay we'll give up the the the
photographs they are documents they are
relevant to your Freedom of Information
Act lawsuit and then the president
backtracks because he's worried about
the backlash uh that will be Unleashed
from the photographs and certainly no
one wants to see a backlash I mean we at
the ACU don't want to see Mayhem or
destruction we don't want to see our
soldiers put in a Harm's Way But frankly
what's going to put our soldiers in a
Harm's Way is not the release of the
photos it's the fact that we've tortured
and abused individuals and we've
captured those very policies on
photographs and videos and the only way
you're going to create the political
will uh to ensure that we never do that
again is to make sure we look at it
straight in the face we have to
understand what really went on to create
the political will to make sure that we
prosecute those who allowed that to
happen and to make sure that we put in
place this sufficient deterrence that
going forward no one else will break the
law quite the way that we saw under the
bush
years well if you're poor or you're
minority the criminal justice system
doesn't work for you you've got you the
the the the deck of cards is stacked
against you and it's clear that that the
the criminal justice system treats
people who have resources or treats
people who are not minorities very
differently we can see that already in
some of the efforts we've begun to
address I mean here you have to give the
Administration some some a great deal of
credit and helping erase the differences
between crack and powder cocaine where
crack cocaine was dealt with much more
aggressively than powdered cocaine and
that was basically a racial disparity it
was mostly whites who would be able to
afford or would use powder cocaine and
often it was minorities and low-income
people using crack cocaine but frankly
when you look at the death penalty and
you look at uh the individuals who often
receive the the death sentences they
often have to do with poor lawyers uh
because we we have not resourced uh the
criminal justice system or the public
defender system well you deal with often
the biases of juries especially in
southern states and places where their
discrimination is still rampant you deal
with politicians and some uh District
Attorneys and States Attorney General
who are using race and crime as a way to
run for office and to Curry the favor of
conservative and often white voters and
so what we have to understand is that
the criminal justice system is really
stacked against people who are poor or
low income and we have to Resource that
system in a way that's much more
significant we still have people going
who are on death row whose lawyers were
asleep during their trials whose lawyers
didn't do Discovery in cases of life or
death who had never done a capital uh
defense case who didn't have access to
the full mitigation and investigative
experts that you need in a death penalty
case in a lot of places we're still
pulling people to death
uh by winging it uh people who are there
and perhaps even are innocent that's one
of the most remarkable things about the
development with DNA evidence it's shown
clearly now that there are people who
have been on death row who now through
DNA evidence we can show we're fully
innocent and have been exonerated more
than a 100 or so individuals over the
period over the last several years that
should make us think twice about the
infallibility of putting someone to
death that should make us think twice
about the fallibility of our criminal
justice system that that should make us
have the political will just to step
back from it and say look this system
doesn't work we need to abolish the
death penalty that no matter how great a
system we construct it will be fallible
and taking someone's life which is the
it's the most irreversible error that
you can ever commit it's just too great
a stake to run the risk that you're
going to put one innocent person to
death and that's why we've always
believed the death penalty should be
utterly and completely abolished no
matter what the set of circumstance sens
no matter what the crime cuz it can
never work and it's certainly not
working well when it comes to low-income
in minority
people well I think if you look at
Canada for instance you have you have
increasing protection for civil
liberties and civil rights they enacted
something similar to the Patriot Act in

from some of those uh law enforcement
Powers you see some of the the the

about how those practices just don't

their own protections for human rights
and so America right now is not leading

liberties America is really trailing uh
trailing the the crowd and unless we
take very definitive steps to restore

we'll prosecute the criminals who broke

tried andrue federal court system that

we're going to continue to Trail the

that the progress we've made despite the
the opposition from the federal

governments it would have been
Unthinkable to me I'm 44 years old uh
two weeks ago when I was growing up I

I think that speaks volumes about the

that these are not equal rights of
ordinary American citizens we saw the

in Def in
uh to defend the Defense of Marriage Act

their civil rights
and I think it's great that he had this

it's it's ridiculous uh they promis to
uh to undo don't ask don't tell they the

saying now that they they'll get to it
in their sweet old their sweet old time
uh it's really quite different if you're

and you can lose your job even if you
you lay down your life for your country
you could still be kicked out uh from
that that post or that that position and

just shows in fact that they're not a

the way we had hoped and that the way

when when folks turned out in record

it's because they wanted to see Swift

you want to protect them and their

a CEO the government workers of the

begin to scratch their heads and

clear around marriage
and in fact the president has said in

he struggles with the idea around

hard uh frankly we don't have the same

you know he is protected by the law the
president is protected by the law he's

the law protects their family uh
protects them from discrimination
protects them in case anything were to

gay people across this country don't

and frankly it the time has come for

months and the institution of marriage I
don't think is any weaker M
Massachusetts than is than it was 3
years ago we've seen it in in
Connecticut and frankly decisive clear
action from the federal government I
think is essential and necessary and
it's still uh not
there frankly the ACLU is almost 90
years old we have to evolve to a
different set of circumstances we have
to understand how things are playing out
sometimes we've made mistakes uh there
have been there was an enormous debate
in at the ACLU during World War II
around Japanese American internment
there were good civil Libertarians who
thought that we ought to give FDR the
benefit of the doubt that it was
necessary to secure the West Coast uh
and therefore in turn Japanese Americans
but fortunately there were other good
civil Libertarians who said no way that
we can never abide that and it was our a
northern California affiliate our
California offices who broke rank
actually with some of the leaders in the
national office and brought the KATU
case the Supreme Court case that we
filed in 1941 lost in 1944
uh where the constitution
constitutionality of Japanese Americans
being interned was upheld by the Supreme
Court and then was some 50 years later
until we got reparations for Japanese
Americans so the ACLU itself has not
always been on the right side of these
issues in the 1950s we had a very
difficult period where in fact our
leadership got too cozy with Hoover's
FBI we were giving the minutes of our of
our meetings we tried so hard to show
that we weren't communist that we
expelled a couple of Communists who were
in the ranks of both the board and the
and the staff of the ACLU and we look
back as an organization and think that
those were some of the saddest moments
in our organization's history that as
good as we can point to the fighting the
interm of Japanese Americans there were
moments when we were uh falling prey to
the Red Scare of the
1950s and part of what we learned from
that I think we continue to learn is the
need to stand up to these abuses of
power no matter who's presentent no
matter how popular no matter how
well-liked no matter what the challenges
we confront in a particular context
that's when we begin to think in ways
that well maybe we should just negotiate
and compromise on some core issues and
some core values that ought not to be
compromised that's when we get into
perilous
terrain at one point the ACLU had a
policy of opposing metal detectors at
airports it was an absolutist approach
to the fact that you know that's an
unreasonable search and seizure over the
years and as we got to understand better
the terrorist threat that does present
at airport in particular we changed that
policy and we said look the most
important thing is to make it as uh as
least intr uh intrusive as possible that
a male detector is really quite
different than strip searching someone
at the airport so we can live with a Mel
detector we won't live with strip
searching all airport passengers and
part of what we've had to do as I think
any organization must do is to adapt and
change to their times but keep an eye on
core principles and keep asking yourself
the question that are we not giving up
the ghost when it comes to really
important values and frankly I think the
way we comported ourselves and the the
Vigor of our descent and the initial
aftermath of 91 where President Bush
began to take more and more law
enforcement Powers we were a lone
voice I started work on September 4th
2001 and I thought as as the first
person to come into the ACLU in over 40
years from outside the organization I
thought that one of my primary goals
would be to help revivify a concern for
civil liberties when I was interviewing
for this job I was 35 years old at the
time a lot of my contemporaries and
friends said it's a wonderful
organization but perhaps it's time had
come and gone that it didn't seem as
organization that was about the current
struggles for civil liberties and civil
rights and so much of the concerns I had
coming in would be how to bring in a new
generation of civil Libertarians how to
show that these issues are not the
issues that our parents or grandparents
fought for and one but the issues for us
and our subsequent generations and then
lo and behold the week later with the
events of September 11th the initial
task which I really hadn't wrapped my
mind around how to do it became much
easier uh to do uh it was clear that the
civil liberties issues that we were
going to be confronting in the aftermath
of 9/11 would be the questions for us
and for our subsequent Generations that
the war on terror would unleash an
enormous assault on civil liberties just
like we had seen during the second world
war during the Vietnam war and other
periods where our nation's been tried
and had difficulties with National
Security or questions around uh
terrorism within the United States and
so we knew we'd be on the front lines uh
who knew though that we would be exactly
as challenged as we were under the bush
years and perhaps it was a bit of
optimism a bit of idealism uh perhaps I
was thinking that our elected officials
or appointed officials would have
learned the mistakes of the past but
what we endured under eight years of
George Bush was absolutely breathtaking
uh no no one would have ever have
imagined for instance that we would be
detaining individuals American citizens
apprehended on American soil without
charge or without access to lawyers it
was unfathomable to think that America
which had always been the champion of
Human Rights and had always denounced
torture and abuse in dictatorships and
